author: Jay Jones
title: Bear watchers head to British Columbia for a special view
text:
Seated in a small boat in a creek along British Columbia's west coast, a handful of people awaited a paradox they would remember forever: the sighting of a black bear with white fur.
The native First Nations people who inhabit this difficult-to-reach rain forest call it the spirit bear, an animal sent by the creator to remind them of the impermeable ice and snow that once covered their land.
Scientists have a different name, Kermode. Despite its white fur, it's neither a polar bear nor an albino. The rare creature results from the mating of two black bears carrying a recessive gene.
Mealtime Douglas Neasloss, Spirit Bear Lodge Grizzlies gorge on salmon during the fall spawning season, before hibernating for the winter. Grizzlies gorge on salmon during the fall spawning season, before hibernating for the winter. (Douglas Neasloss, Spirit Bear Lodge) The yearning to see a spirit bear is what lured Anna and John Ayre to this coast, the only place on the planet where the bears are found. The Ayres are among a small but growing number of wildlife enthusiasts traveling to remote bear-viewing lodges along the British Columbia coast.
Patience paid off last September as a young spirit bear rambled along the creek bed not far from the Ayres and their fellow visitors.
"When you see the bear, it's like a magical experience. Your whole body is suspended somehow," Anna Ayre said of the remarkable sighting during the Hendersonville, N.C., couple's second visit to Spirit Bear Lodge in the tiny native village of Klemtu. As his wife watched in awe, John Ayre clicked away with his camera. Photos, not a bear rug, would be their trip's trophies.
Such contact isn't uncommon when the salmon are spawning and the bears are hungry. Tim McGrady, the lodge's general manager, was guiding some guests when they witnessed two spirit bears together last fall.

"The mom had obviously spent a lot of time around us over the years and was introducing her cub to these strange humans that come and sit and watch them."
Scattered lodges dot the sprawling Great Bear Rainforest along the stunning Inside Passage waterway, about 70 minutes by air north of Vancouver. It often takes three or four flights in commercial aircraft, plus a ride in a floatplane or boat, to reach the habitat of spirit bears, their kindred black bears and grizzlies. Those who have experienced the close encounters say they're well worth the effort â€” and the expense.
"We let the bears pretty much set the distance," noted Tom Rivest, owner of Great Bear Lodge on Smith Inlet, a 30-minute flight from Port Hardy. Sometimes, the bears will calmly stroll to within 10 feet of the human visitors.
"Our behavior is fairly ritualized," said Rivest, a wildlife biologist. "The animals that know us often will just look up, but they know what's going on, so they go back to feeding and don't look at us again."
The bears sometimes become so comfortable that they allow the camera-toting humans to baby-sit.
"A huge grizzly bear mama brought her cubs within, I'd say, about 15 feet of us and parked them there," Spirit Bear Lodge's Tim McGrady said. "They just fell on top of each other and snoozed while she went off along the river to fish. She came back about half an hour later with this massive chum salmon, picked up her cubs and headed off into the forest.
"Without that human presence, you'd never see a mom leave her cubs for that length of time," he continued. "That's the kind of experience we have fairly regularly with bears."
 While the season runs from May to October, the best time to see an abundance of bears is late summer and early fall. That's when they feast on fish before moving to their winter dens to hibernate.
"We have a 10-week, very intensive peak season where we'll see upwards of 400 people come into this little village, literally from around the world," McGrady said.
Visitors to Klemtu are greeted by drum-beating locals, many of whom have never ventured outside the town. The Kitasoo/Xaixais band (community) owns the lodge; most of the employees are natives.
"It's a really neat, cross-cultural experience," McGrady noted. "(Guests) go away with a really different notion of this culture that's existed along the coast for at least the last 9,000 to 10,000 years."
There's tension, though, in the rain forest. Sport hunting is legal in the province, and rifle-toting visitors come in hopes of shooting a grizzly or black bear. Hunting spirit bears is illegal.
"That's a real conflict for us," McGrady said, adding that 10 native bands try to prohibit hunting on their land.
"Trophy hunting is not a part of their culture," he observed. "They never hunted for sport. They hunted for food."
A 2013 opinion poll revealed that 87 percent of British Columbians believe bear hunting should be banned. As funds allow, the Raincoast Conservation Foundation, based in Sidney, British Columbia, is buying up hunting rights in the Great Bear Rainforest to keep commercial operators from organizing hunts.
"In our view, there is no ecological, no economic or ethical reason to be killing these bears for recreation," the foundation's Chris Genovali said.
Jay Jones is a freelance writer.
If you go
Bear-viewing adventures can be expensive. A three-day all-inclusive visit to Great Bear Lodge (888-221-8212, http://www.greatbeartours.com ) in high season costs $3,380 Canadian (about $2,740 U.S.) per person double occupancy. Guests pay for their own transportation to Port Hardy, B.C.
A seven-day, all-inclusive package in high season at Spirit Bear Lodge (250-339-5644, http://www.spiritbear.com ) runs $6,060 Canadian (about US$4,910) per person double occupancy. The trips begin in Vancouver.
A cheaper alternative is a day trip by boat to the Khutzymateen Grizzly Bear Sanctuary north of Prince Rupert, B.C. Prince Rupert Adventure Tours (800-201-8377, http://www.adventuretours.net ) offers seven-hour trips for $245 Canadian (about US$198), daily May 10 to Aug. 5.
